title: Protocol for global proteome, virome, and metaproteome profiling of respiratory specimen (VTM) in COVID-19 patient by LC-MS/MS-based analysis
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Heat inactivation of virus (Batejat et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1])
Timing: 30 min
Note: By the end of this step, the virus gets inactivated, and now all the remaining sample processing steps can be performed in the BSL-2 facility.
Caution: SARS-CoV-2 Samples should be handled in a Biosafety Level 3 (BSL-3) laboratory using BSL-3 practices till virus inactivation is performed and post inactivation, all other steps can be performed on BSL-2 facility.
Nasopharyngeal samples (NPS) and oropharyngeal samples together were collected into 1 mL of viral transport media.
Around 500 uL of the sample was incubated with a pre-warmed dry heating block maintained at 92°C for 15 min.
Homogenization of respiratory specimen (Dowling et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7])
Timing: 5–7 min per sample
Note: By the end of this step, all the cell's macromolecules like proteins, metabolites, lipids, etc., will be released in solution.
Respiratory specimens may contain host cells, mucus, bacterial and viral components. Thus, it is essential to homogenize the samples.
Caution: The high-frequency sound emitted by the Sonicator can damage hearing; therefore, place the sample in a noise isolating chamber and always close the door while operating. Do not grasp an activated horn or touch the tip of a vibrating probe. It can cause severe tissue damage and burns.
Take 500 μL of respiratory specimen in a new microcentrifuge tube (MCT) and keep it on the ice during homogenization.
Place the sample in a noise isolating chamber and submerge the Sonicator probe into the sample.
Note: The probe should not touch the walls of MCT as it will break the tube and destroy the sample.
Close the door of the chamber after properly placing the sample tube.

Run the program at Power 20%, Run time 5 min (Cycle – 10 s ON, 10 s OFF) and temperature 22°C.
Remove and wipe the probe with ethanol.
Note: Keep the sample on the ice during all the homogenization steps step 2–6.
Pause point: Respiratory specimen can be stored at −80°C for up to 4 weeks.
Organic solvent-mediated protein precipitation (Bradford, 1976[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]; Simpson and Beynon, 2010[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12])
Timing: 90 min
Note: By the end of this step, all proteins will be precipitated.
200 uL of VTM was placed in acetone compatible tube.
Add the 6-fold volume of cold acetone to VTM.
Vortex and incubate for 1–4 h at −80°C.
Centrifuge for 10 min at 18,000 g.
Carefully decant the supernatant without disturbing the protein pellet.
Allow pellet to air dry for 10–30 min in an uncapped tube. (Do not over dry otherwise, the pellet may not resuspend properly)
Resuspend the pellet in 50 uL of Ammonium Bicarbonate Buffer (ABC buffer).
Protein estimation using Bradford assay (Bradford, 1976[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4])
Timing: 30 min
Note: By the end of this step, the protein concentration of all samples can be quantified.
To prepare BSA standards and associated calibration curve, make a stock solution of 2 mg/mL of BSA in PBS.
Now label vials A to I, and add the stock or the master solution and Buffer as directed in the table below to achieve the desired results concentration of standard.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1306_19.csv
In a 96 well plate, 5 uL of pre-prepared BSA standards along with blank were added.
5 uL of unknown samples was also loaded.
Now to each well, 245 uL of Bradford reagent was added.
Keep it on a shaker for 15–30 s.
Now incubate at 25°C for 10 min in the dark.
Take absorbance at 595 nm within 60 min post-incubation.

Plot a standard absorbance curve at 595 nm on the "Y" axis versus the protein concentration on the "X" axis.
Record the value "x" of unknown samples from the graph corresponding to absorbance reading and determine the protein concentration.
SDS PAGE mediated intra-sample variability detection (Nowakowski et al., 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10])
Timing: 5 h
Note: By the end of this step, the intrasample variability among samples and in their associated group can be detected.
In-gel casting apparatus assemble glass plates and spacers.
Mix the component of resolving gel (12%).
Pour the resolving gel mixture between the gel plates till a level 2 cm below the top of the shorter plate.
Pace a layer of Distilled H2O over the top of the resolving gel to prevent meniscus formation in the resolving gel.
Incubate resolving gel for 30 min at 25°C
Drain the water from the top of the resolving gel and wick any remaining water away with a Kimwipe.
Mix stacking gel components and pour into gel plates (on top of resolving gel) to fill the gel plates.
Insert comb at the top of the spacers.
Remove the comb and assemble cast gel into the SDS apparatus.
Add 1× bromophenol blue to each sample.
Add freshly prepared 1× running buffer to both chambers of the apparatus
Now load DNA ladder in first well, 5 ug BSA in another well, and 30 ug equivalent unknown sample protein in other wells.
Run the gel at 100 V till the dye front migrates into the running gel (∼15 min) and then increase to 120 V until the dye front reaches the bottom of the gel (∼1.5 h.).
Now Remove the gel from the apparatus and by removing the spacers and glass plates.
Place the gel into a small tray.

Note: Never use a metal spatula to separate the glass plates.
Add ∼25 mL staining solution and incubate for > 30 min with gentle shaking.
Add ∼5 mL destaining solution and destain for ∼1 min with gentle shaking, then Pour off and discard the destain solution.
Further, add ∼ 30 mL of destain solution and destain with gentle shaking until the gel is visibly distained (> 2 h).
Pour off and discard the destain solution and rewash the gel with distilled water.
Visualize on GelDoc.
In-solution protein digestion (Gundry et al., 2009[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8])
Timing: 26 h
Note: By the end of this step, all the proteins will be digested, and tryptic peptides will be generated.
50 ug equivalent proteins are diluted using the buffer till the final volume becomes 100 uL.
Add 20 uL of 10 mM Dithiothreitol (DTT) and incubate at 60°C for 1 h in a water bath to reduce proteins.
Post-reduction, add 15 uL of 10 mM Iodoacetamide and incubate for 30 min in the dark for alkylation of proteins,
Add 5 uL of modified sequencing grade trypsin (1 ug/5 uL) reconstituted in 100 uL ABC buffer.
Incubate at 37°C for 20–24 h in a water bath.
After incubation, add 5 uL of 0.1% (v/v) Formic acid to the reaction mixture to inhibit trypsin activity.
C18 column mediated desaltation of peptides (Dowling et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7])
Timing: 90 min
Note: By the end of this step, all the contaminants, e.g., salt, will be removed.
Please open a new Pierce C18 column, place it in an empty 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube,
Incubate it with 250 uL of Buffer C for 5 min (Column Washing).
Centrifuge for 2 min on a tabletop centrifuge and discard the flowthrough.

Add 200 uL of Buffer A in the column, then incubate for 2 min (Column Washing).
Centrifuge for 2 min on a tabletop centrifuge and discard the flowthrough.
Add 200 uL of Buffer B in the column,
Incubate for 2 min (Column equilibration).
Discard the flowthrough.
Now load the digested sample.
Incubate it for 5 min.
Centrifuge for 2 min on a tabletop centrifuge and then reload the flowthrough (peptide-binding).
Incubate again for 5 min and repeat step 49.
Repeat steps 49 and 50 two more times.
Centrifuge for 2 min on a tabletop centrifuge and discard the flowthrough.
Add 200 uL of Buffer B in the column, then incubate for 2 min (Washing).
Centrifuge for 2 min on a tabletop centrifuge and discard the flowthrough.
Add 30 uL of Buffer C and Centrifuge for 2 min on a tabletop centrifuge.
Repeat step 55.
Finally, add 40 uL Buffer C and Centrifuge for 2 min on a tabletop centrifuge.
Take the flowthrough and discard the used column.
Lyophilize the samples at 4°C and 60 millibar pressure till the sample is dry (do not over dry sample; otherwise, they will be tough to reconstitute).
Reconstitute in 40 uL of 0.1% (v/v) Formic acid.
Centrifuge at 15,000 g for and load the supernatant in an HPLC vial.
LC-MS/MS analysis (Bhat et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]; Das et al., 2017[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6], 2019[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]; Dowling et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7])
Timing: 180 min per sample
Note: By the end of this step, the MS.raw files would be curated.
The peptides were ionized by nano-electrospray and subsequent tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) on a Q-ExactiveTM Plus (Thermo Fisher Scientific, San Jose, CA, United States).

The peptides were eluted by a 3–95% gradient of buffer B (aqueous 80% acetonitrile in 0.1% formic acid) with a continuous flow rate of 300 nL/min for about 60 min on a 25-cm analytical C18 column (C18, 3 mm, 100 A).
The peptides were analyzed using a mass spectrometer with the collision-induced dissociation mode with the electrospray voltage 2.3 kV.
Analysis on the orbitrap was performed with full scan MS spectra with a resolution of 70,000 from m/z 350 to 1800. Mascot algorithm (Mascot 2.4, Matrix Science).
Significant proteins were identified at (p < 0.05) and q values (p < 0.05). The threshold of false discovery rate was kept at 0.01.
Database curation for host proteome, metaproteome, and virome (Maras et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9])
Note: By the end of this step, the database would be curated on which MS.raw files would be mapped.
The raw files generated post-LC-MS/MS analysis were analyzed using Proteome discoverer 2.2 for protein identification and quantification.
One of the most crucial parts is database curation, against which the mass spectrometric files need to be searched. So, in our case, we created three databases: a Virome (COVID) database, another for humans, and one for metaproteome.
To curate the database, visit https://www.uniprot.org/proteomes/[href=https://www.uniprot.org/proteomes/].
Find proteome for your organism of interest by searching for them from proteome ID, e.g., UP000005640 – Homo sapiens) or taxonomic name or ID.
Now click on the download button> Select all protein entries > Fasta (canonical, compressed, and isoform). (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1])

Always prefer the reviewed databases because reviewed databases are carefully annotated with minimal redundancy and can integrate into other databases efficiently.
